columns.text: In this problem, we are asked to determine the personal tax rate and explain each scenario.
**Personal Tax Rate** - is a tax rate levied on individuals or businesses in relation to their earnings or profits.

## Requirement 1

To begin, we will let x be the personal tax rate. After the dividend, the individual will receive $1,000 (1-x%), which he will invest in treasury bonds. Now, if the treasury bonds will generate after-tax cash flows to the investors, the equation will:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Investment in Treasury Bond} &= \text{\$1,000(1 - x\%)} \times {[1+0.03(1 - x\%)]}\\[1pt]
\end{aligned}$$

Then, if the firm invests the money, the proceeds will be computed as:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Investment in Treasury Bond} &= \text{\$1,000(1 - x\%)} \times {[1+0.03(1 - 0.35)]}\\[1pt]
\end{aligned}$$

We can now compute the personal tax rate using the equation in step 3 and 4.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{\$1,000(1 - x\%)} \times {[1+0.03(1 - x\%)]}&= \text{\$1,000(1 - x\%)} \times {[1+0.03(1 - 0.35)]}\\[5pt]
{[1+0.03(1 - x\%)]}&=  {[1+0.03(1 - 0.35)]}\\[5pt]
\text{1+(0.03 - 0.03x\%)}&=\text  {[1+0.03(0.65)]}\\[5pt]
\text{ 0.03x\%}&=\text  {1.03 -1.0195}\\[5pt]
\text{ 0.03x\%}&=\text  {1.03 -1.0195}\\[5pt]
\text{ 0.03x\%}&=\text  {0.0105}\\[5pt]
x\% &= \dfrac{0.0105}{0.03}\\[5pt]
&= \boxed{\textbf{35\%}}
\end{aligned}$$

 Therefore, the personal tax rate that make the investors equally willing to receive the dividend or to let Carlson invest the money is **35%.**

## Requirement b

The personal tax rate of 35% is reasonable to let Carlson invest the money because personal tax rate is equal to corporate tax rate.

## Requirement c

Next, suppose the only investment choice is preferred stock that yields 6 percent and the corporate tax exclusion is 70%. We will now compute personal tax rate. Now that we will let x be the personal tax rate.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{\$1,000(1 - x\%)} \times {[1+0.06(1 - x\%)]}&= \text{\$1,000(1 - x\%)} \times {[1+0.06(1 - 0.35)(0.70 + (1-0.70))]}\\[5pt]
 {[1+0.06(1 - x\%)]}&=  {[1+0.06(1 - 0.35)(0.70 + (1-0.70))]}\\[5pt]


\text{1+(0.06 - 0.06x\%)}&={[1+0.06(0.65)(0.70 + 0.30))]}
\\[5pt]
\text{1.06 - 0.06x\%)}&={[1+0.06(0.65)(1))]}\\[5pt]
\text{1.06 - 0.06x\%)}&={1.0378}\\[5pt]
\text{ 0.06x\%}&=\text  {1.06 -1.039}\\[5pt]
\text{ 0.06x\%}&=\text  {0.0222}\\[5pt]
x\% &= \dfrac{0.0222}{0.06}\\[5pt]
&= \boxed{\textbf{35\%}}
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the personal tax rate that will make the stockholders indifferent to the outcome of Carlsonâ€™s dividend decision is **35\%**.

## Requirement d

**Yes**, it is a compelling argument for a low dividend payout ratio because the company has personal tax rate of **35%** and it shows that they have enough funds to increase dividends in the future.
